Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: The Response of African Monsoon Variability to Elevated CO2 and Implications for Future Atlantic Tropical Cyclone Activity
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will provide new insights into the long-standing problem of understanding future tropical cyclone (TC) activity. The results will provide valuable information for future planning of resource management in water sensitive regions of the African Sahel and infrastructure of coastal communities affected by Atlantic TCs.

The primary goal of this project is to explore how the dynamics of African Easterly Waves (AEW) respond to a climate forcing of doubled atmospheric CO2 and determine the implications for future Atlantic TC activity. This will be achieved through a suite of simulations with a coupled and super-parameterized global climate model that uses embedded cloud resolving models to reproduce a realistic interaction between convection and large-scale processes. Additional sensitivity experiments will be conducted to isolate the slow and fast responses of the climate system, and examine how they affect AEWs. The analysis will also identify how future AEWs will affect Atlantic TC activity through consideration of the marsupial paradigm and remote influences on the Atlantic TC genesis potential.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The uncertainty of how tropical cyclone (TC) activity will respond to warming from elevated CO2 was a key motivation for this project, but instead of focusing on TC’s themselves I took a unique approach of focusing on the primary TC precursor disturbance in the Atlantic basin, known as “African easterly waves”. These waves originate in the African monsoon, which is why my analysis centered around this region.

 

The advantage of this approach is that a global climate model (GCM) with grid spacing of ~100 km can resolve African easterly waves, whereas TCs require a grid spacing of ~25 km or less, which is much more expensive. The other novel aspect of this project was the use of super-parameterization (SP), which is a technique for replacing traditional GCM parameterizations for moist convection, radiation, microphysics, and turbulence, with a cloud resolving model (CRM) so these process can explicitly interact on the scale of individual clouds. SP models produce more realistic convective behavior compared to traditional climate models, and are thus well suited to study convectively coupled phenomena, such as easterly waves. Previous research has shown that SP models produce very robust African easterly wave activity, which makes SP model simulations an ideal tool for studying their response to warming from elevated CO2.

 

Two simulations were conducted with pre-industrial (1x) and quadrupled (4x) levels of CO2. The immediate result was a reduction in Easterly wave activity in the mid-troposphere (~600 hPa) over the African Sahel region (5°:10°N, -20°:10°E; see Fig. 1). There is also stronger low-level wave activity around 15°:20°N that has been found in previous studies, and is a well understood consequence of stronger warming in the Sahara that enhances the meridional temperature gradient.

 

The distribution of wave events reveals that the reduction of southern wave activity is associated with less frequent weak waves, while stronger waves becomes slightly more frequent (see Fig. 2). The explanation of this result lies in the systematic change of a vortex stretching process that is caused by the increase in static stability from the warming. This mechanism applies to the portion of the wave that is south of 10°N, so it will likely not directly affect tropical cyclogenesis, but it may still be responsible for altering TC activity by changing the future distribution of Atlantic TC seed disturbances. Other mechanisms were found to be at play, but they are heavily influenced by large-scale model biases in the SST pattern, and are likely model dependent.


This study adds to the growing literature on SP models, which are likely to be used more widely by climate scientists as the power of available computing resources increases. Wider adoption of SP models will help to illuminate regional climate responses in areas where moist convection plays a driving role in the weather variability, and thus provide a valuable resource for formulating adaptation strategies. While the actual results of this study are not directly applicable to answering specific questions about future Atlantic TC activity, the mechanism I have identified may provide useful insight for further studies on this subject. The mechanism is also applicable to other modes of Tropical synoptic scale weather (ex. equatorial Kelvin wave), which will be the subject of future research.
